<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_init:
```c
void metal_io_init(struct metal_io_region *io, void *virt,
	      const metal_phys_addr_t *physmap, size_t size,
	      unsigned int page_shift, unsigned int mem_flags,
	      const struct metal_io_ops *ops)
{
	const struct metal_io_ops nops = {
		NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
	};

	io->virt = virt;
	io->physmap = physmap;
	io->size = size;
	io->page_shift = page_shift;
	if (page_shift >= sizeof(io->page_mask) * CHAR_BIT)
		/* avoid overflow */
		io->page_mask = -1UL;
	else
		io->page_mask = (1UL << page_shift) - 1UL;
	io->mem_flags = mem_flags;
	io->ops = ops ? *ops : nops;
	metal_sys_io_mem_map(io);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
io->size = size;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the statement io->size = size is a plain assignment and does not call any <string.h> functions. Rule 21.17 concerns use of string.h functions (memcpy, strcpy, etc.) that may access beyond object bounds; this assignment by itself cannot cause such an out-of-bounds access. (A violation would arise only if io->size were later used as a length in a string.h call that copies more bytes than the destination can hold.)
